Review: Maybe the first Sriram Raghavan film I'm not enamoured by. And by no fault of the screenplay, which finds him in a delightful new mood (the nod to Shakti Samanta is handholding enough). To my mind he's also a crisp filmmaker with a penchant for visual evocations of a time gone by. Ironic that his actual period film is a collection of unflattering, flat shots that don't really come together except maybe in the final act. Sometimes when he cuts…

I'm the biggest advocate of long films unless it's Bollywood. These people are so obsessed with plot they'll waste three hours milking it every which way till its teets dry. Dunki is exactly the kind of film I expected it to be, and that's not a good thing. Hirani extracts an Aamir performance from SRK, so weird. Like a typical Raju Hirani lead he seems to have a presence because of his world serving, self sacrificing ways except the dialogs…

no one can understand how starved we are for good vibes hindi language cinema. Great bombay film. Follows in the late 90s-early 00s tradition of great first films from ad-filmmakers about urban middle class with a great sense of place, people and music.

jaggu dada gets to be an old and lonely matunga uncle and that's reason enough to watch it. I'm always starved for a Bombay film, and I'd trust Vijay Maurya to get that right. He does. Seldom do we see representation of the everyday underbelly of Bombay populated by Eastern UP bhaiyaas speaking really deep cut dialects. Great cast all around including Rakhi Sawant but excluding Neena Gupta, whose casting is a mistake that almost undoes this film. She's been…
a vanga protagonist unironically waltzing in to a manbun cover of dick hai chhota sa, chhoti si aasha is quite fitting

Thought this sucked, the samurai baiting on the poster just adds to it. So many interesting places it could have gone but kanagaraj chose to make a cg mess out of it instead. I realise now how much of Vikram works because of Kamala Hasan, actors can rarely do that thing he does. Vijay is a charisma and acting black hole. I've never seen someone smile so unnaturally all the time.

The beginning of this film was one of the most effective touch grass moments for me in films. Felt like I was right outside that bus tasting asphalt when the Syrian refugees started deboarding, slurs being hurled at them. The kind of realism that nobody is able to achieve like Ken Loach, largely because he remains a fairly radical octogenarian. You'd think someone so late in their style wouldn't care for the aesthetics of their film, which is why it's…
wondered if I could give any less of a shit about a movie

Kaurismaki greatest hits, what's not to love? A lover waiting to be found outside the theatre, in a bus, in a dingy bar, or a public garden. A comrade from the lowest rung, soul destroying job helping you get through the night by exchanging blows and drinks in a filthy bar. The hope of finding love in autumn underscores the desolate lives of working folks in Kaurismaki's world. And that's all the fuel you need to fight. Like a communist poet who'd write the most crushingly beautiful poems about loving someone.

Movie: Do Not Expect Too Much from the End of the World

Review: radicalised me, converted me, got me on my knees
Wasn't no harm in him. You'd give him a flower, he'd keep it forever.
